data.title: Add default choices in the integrated terminal dropdown menu.
data.body:
It can be a pain trying to help someone properly setup a 64 bit cmd or PowerShell terminal. Since Code uses %comspec% as it's default terminal, this breaks a lot of things on 64 bit machines. 

To make dealing with this easier, I think there should be a drop down similar to the terminal selection one where we can configure multiple terminals.  Then Code can add some of the native ones as default values and allow users to add new ones.

Example on windows 64bit:

``` json
"terminal.integrated.shell.windows.options": { 
    "PowerShell (x64)": "C:\\WINDOWS\\sysnative\\WindowsPowerShell\\v1.0\\powershell.exe",
    "PowerShell (x86)": "C:\\WINDOWS\\system32\\WindowsPowerShell\\v1.0\\powershell.exe",
    "Cmd (x64)": "C:\\WINDOWS\\sysnative\\cmd.exe",
    "Cmd (x86)": "C:\\WINDOWS\\system32\\cmd.exe"
}
```

Example on windows 32bit:

``` json
"terminal.integrated.shell.windows.options": { 
    "PowerShell": "C:\\WINDOWS\\system32\\WindowsPowerShell\\v1.0\\powershell.exe",
    "Cmd": "C:\\WINDOWS\\system32\\cmd.exe"
}
```

You could also do something to add Shell Args in there as well, which I am really hoping Windows gets some day.

data.title: Allow new editor to open with an empty file
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4.0-insider
- OS Version: macOS 10.11.5

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Close all other editors, work on a file, make some changes.
2. Press <kbd>⌘</kbd> + <kbd>\</kbd> to open a new editor.
3. You want to work on another file in this editor and don't need the first file to be open here as well. But you can't close that file without first saving it. If you choose not to save, your changes are lost even in the first editor.

Point being, opening the same file in the new editor is a sensible default. But an option to not do so (perhaps with <kbd>Shift</kbd> + <kbd>⌘</kbd> + <kbd>\</kbd>) should also be provided which would just open a new editor with an empty file and not continue with the one already open in the old editor.

Edit: I just remembered <kbd>Shift</kbd> + <kbd>⌘</kbd> + <kbd>\</kbd> is already taken, so maybe some other. The other shortcuts to open/re-focus editors <kbd>⌘</kbd> + <kbd>2</kbd> / <kbd>3</kbd> could also be extended.

data.title: Middle click scrolling in the Tabs section after closing file
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 64bits

**Steps to Reproduce:**
1. Open a lot of tabs to have a horizontal scroll in the `Tabs` section
2. Middle click a file

**What happens:**

It closes the file while putting the scrolling cursor (the 4 arrows) and you have to click elsewhere to stop scrolling.

https://gfycat.com/ColorlessPiercingDuckling to see it in action

**What is expected:**

It should close the file without any scrolling or the need to click somewhere else after doing it.

data.title: Fail running run build task.
data.body:
This used to work just before i turn off my laptop.
- VSCode Version: 1.3.1
- OS Version: El capitan OS X

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Have configured a tasks.json file.
2. Run build tasks (shift+cmd+B)

Will throw this error on any project:

```
Failed to launch external program tsc -p ..
spawn tsc ENOENT
```

This is my tasks.json

``` json
{
  "version": "0.1.0",
  "command": "tsc",
  "isShellCommand": true,
  "args": ["-p", "."],
  "showOutput": "silent",
  "problemMatcher": "$tsc"
}
```

And my launch.json

``` json
{
  "version": "0.2.0",
  "configurations": [
    {
      "name": "Debug Android",
      "program": "${workspaceRoot}/.vscode/launchReactNative.js",
      "type": "reactnative",
      "request": "launch",
      "platform": "android",
      "internalDebuggerPort": 9090,
      "sourceMaps": true,
      "outDir": "${workspaceRoot}/.vscode/.react"
    },
    {
      "name": "Debug iOS",
      "program": "${workspaceRoot}/.vscode/launchReactNative.js",
      "type": "reactnative",
      "request": "launch",
      "platform": "ios",
      "target": "iPhone 5s",
      "internalDebuggerPort": 9090,
      "sourceMaps": true,
      "outDir": "${workspaceRoot}/.vscode/.react"
    }
  ]
}
```

data.title: Allow to move a file by adding path segments to rename box

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4.0-insider
- OS Version: any

Feature request:
1. Right click + Rename or hit Enter on selected file to rename the file
2. Allow to not only change name but also to move the file, eg `test.ts` -> `../my-test.ts` would rename the file but also move it up one level

data.title: Integrated Terminal - selection disappears on scroll
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.1
- OS Version: Ubuntu 14.04 (fully updated)

Steps to Reproduce:
1. enter or output text to the integrated terminal; enough to allow scrolling
2. highlight some text
3. scroll up or down using the mouse wheel

Noticed while highlighting some database output for stare-and-compare.

data.title: Integrated Terminal: ctrl-c doesn't work in PowerShell and cmd.exe

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.31
- OS Version: Windows

Steps to Reproduce:
In version 1.3.1 I noticed that ctrl-c does not work and prevents exiting the current command.  In my case I configured terminal to open PowerShell.

Example:

```
PS: >mkdir
cmdlet mkdir at command pipeline position 1
Supply values for the following parameters:
Path[0]:  <<ctrl-c should exit but it does not work>>
```

data.title: Inability to create file/folder at root location
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4.0-insider
- OS Version: OSX 10.11.5

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open project that has only directories at root level (and have them a lot - so you need to scroll)
2. Click any folder
3. Try to create folder / file at the root

It won't be possible because there is no space to click to unselect the folder and hence impossible to create new folder or file at the root.

Moreover in the following screen - its not really clear where it will create file / folder (current folder is not highlighted)

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1723815/16877279/58053c3c-4a75-11e6-94e5-7ed25329b7d6.png)

If I click new folder it creates in: 

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1723815/16877296/676b374e-4a75-11e6-923c-2ee42048e4d2.png)

but as you can see on first screenshot - it was impossible to tell it will create in that folder

data.title: Duplicate file
data.body:
Feature request: Ability to duplicate file
1. Right click file in Explorer
2. New option: "Duplicate" 

which would open mini popup (or some other way) that I could provide new name for duplicated file

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1723815/16876961/136cf0e8-4a74-11e6-9650-674048126b2b.png)

data.title: Fix typo
自动升级文件破损但VSCODE没有提供删除安装包的路径导致无法升级
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.1
- OS Version: windows 10 version 1151

Steps to Reproduce:
1. 检查更新
2. 立即更新

软件本身没有功能问题，是设计失误。因为网络原因，自动下载的升级包下载不完整，点击安装后提示出现错误，但是**没有告诉用户软件自动下载的升级安装文件在哪里**，所以用户没法删除这个文件，也就没法自动升级。

data.title: Only activate a Language when a file is opened in the editor

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- Open a JS file 
- Hover over a variable that refers to a type defined in a .d.ts file, 

-> The TS language is activated.

The reason is that TS language Mode is instantiated to color the TypeScript type name shown in the hover.

The proposal is to only activate the TS language when a .ts file is opened in an editor.

see also #9248

data.title: [theme] Wrong coloring in for cycle and break whole coloring
Give more context: Grammar is in an endless loop - Grammar is not advancing, nor is it pushing/popping
data.body:
Just noticed this in selfhost, is there any chance we could print more info on the error like the resource that caused it?

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/900690/16875291/fd7c6edc-4a9e-11e6-8ece-fa3ff2dbab6c.png)

data.title: Moving an editor across groups does not carry over text view state
data.body:
Steps to Reproduce:
1. have tabs enabled 
2. change the selection in a file to drag
3. move a tab to another group or trigger a split by moving it to the edge

=> after drop, the view state is not the same as it was

Fix is to save the view state of the dragged editor and restore it in the target.

data.title: List widget doesn't respond to touch
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.3.1 (e6b4afa53e9c0f54edef1673de9001e9f0f547ae, 2016-07-12T13:35:06.227Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.10586

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open any document with IntelliSense support
2. Press Ctrl + space to open suggestions
3. Use touch to choose one of the available options

It's impossible to use IntelliSense on touch only devices. Touch keyboard (Windows 10) doesn't have up/down arrows and IntelliSense suggestions doesn't support touch events.

![capture](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1280399/16875132/0995345c-4a9e-11e6-9026-3c4221cc8e50.JPG)

1. Start debugging with an external console window
2. The console window contains a first line with the debugger listening info

4. `console.log("test")` will be printed with a space in front.
5. All following lines are ok

data.title: [bug] Behavior editor on press keys Shift+Tab
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.1
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1.  Open a new document
2.  Type "if () {}" (without quotes)
3.  Press key Home (and cursor go to first column)
4.  Press tab 2 times
5.  Go cursor at |{ (| represents cursor)
6.  Press tab 3 times
7.  Press Shift+Tab (behavior expected woud be back only {, but he back all line, this is annoying)

data.title: Add commands to move tabs left and right in group

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.3.1 (e6b4afa53e9c0f54edef1673de9001e9f0f547ae, 2016-07-12T13:31:10.994Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 15.5.0

I was looking for a command to move an editor within a group, but `workbench.action.moveActiveEditor{Left,Right}` was deprecated (now there are only commands for moving groups).

data.title: Linux/Fedora24: Upgrade from 1.2.1 to 1.3.1 breaks launcher
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Upgrade to 1.3.1 from 1.2.1
- OS Version: Fedora24

Steps to Reproduce:
1. download 1.3.1 rpm package
2. "sudo dnf install _path_to_rpm_"
3. attempt to start vscode via the launcher

-> "failed to launch child process: /usr/bin/code not found: no such file or directory"

Workaround:
1. download 1.3.1 rpm package
2. "sudo dnf remove code"
3. "sudo dnf install _path_to_rpm_"

data.title: Multi-cursors no longer blink in sync
data.body:
Due to the fact that they blink via CSS animations, each cursor's animation begins when it is revealed (when the dom node for the new cursor that enters the viewport gets created):

![blinking](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5047891/16873146/fd48c712-4a99-11e6-8281-951c7ded0098.gif)

data.title: how to make a preview editor permanent w/o editing or mouse?
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.3.1 (e6b4afa53e9c0f54edef1673de9001e9f0f547ae, 2016-07-12T13:31:10.994Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 15.5.0

`Go to File` opens a preview editor per default, which is fine, but, how do I keep a tab open without having to double click it, edit its content or move it to another group?

Maybe it's a good idea to have:
- a command to make a preview editor permanent
- some modifier key for the `Go to File` dialogue to switch the default open mode (e.g. `shift+enter` to open permanently when `workbench.editor.enablePreviewFromQuickOpen` is true and vice versa).

data.title: Select all does not focus editor if targeting the editor
data.body:
Steps to Reproduce:
1. focus to explorer 
2. edit > select all

=> the editor selects all, but focus is not in the editor

data.title: Editor area zoom in display issue

- OS Version: Mac OS X 10.11.5, Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

```
"editor.mouseWheelZoom": true,
```

Problem:

Text is too small to view.


data.title: Unwanted generated tsconfig.json file
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.1
- OS Version: macOS (10.11.5)

Steps to Reproduce:
1.  open terminal
2. cd to project dir
3. launch vscode with `code .` command
4. tsconfig.json file is automatically generated

Is there a way to stop this tsconfig file from being generated? My project is actually js and I have a proper jsconfig.json defined but the tsconfig.json is causing a bunch of syntax error highlighting.
